results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response: Basic EPS per share is calculated as follows:
results.csv_string_response: Basic EPS is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding, which includes common stock options, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards.
results.json_rows_response:
Basic earnings per share, or EPS, is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
For purposes of this calculation, common stock options, restricted stock units and restricted stock awards are considered to be common stock equivalents and are only included in the calculation of diluted EPS when their effect is dilutive. In periods in which the Company has a net loss, dilutive common stock equivalents are excluded from the calculation of diluted EPS.

results.question: Why was the disallowance of the shorter deductibility period would not affect the annual effective tax rate but would accelerate the payment of cash to the taxing authority to an earlier period?
gold_answer: Because of the impact of deferred tax accounting
results.markdown_table_response: The effect of the longer deductibility period is that the liability for deferred tax assets and liabilities is amortized over a longer period of time. In this case, the longer deductibility period resulted in a net annual cash payment to the taxing authority of $325.0 million ($325.0 million less the tax benefit of $257.7 million). In addition, the effect of the longer deductibility period is that the tax liability for gross unrecognized tax benefits was amortized over a longer period of time. In this case, the net tax liability for the deferred tax assets and liabilities was $44.1 million ($44.1 million less $257.7 million), which was accelerated to the earlier period. The effect of the shorter deductibility period is that the tax liability for gross unrecognized tax benefits is amortized over a shorter period of time. In this case, the net tax liability for the deferred tax assets and liabilities was $32.5 million ($32.5 million less $257.7 million), which was accelerated to the earlier period.
